questions.text: In a hospital setting, a physician is considering the risk factors that may trigger acute asthma exacerbations in a patient. Which of the following classes of drugs is known to potentially precipitate acute asthma?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) NSAIDs

 

  • Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) can precipitate acute asthma attacks in some patients.
  • This occurs because NSAIDs inhibit cyclooxygenase enzymes, leading to a shunting of arachidonic acid metabolism towards the leukotriene pathway.
  • Increased leukotriene production can cause bronchoconstriction and inflammation in susceptible individuals, thus triggering or worsening asthma symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. H1 blockers: Incorrect. H1 antihistamines (H1 blockers) are generally safe in asthma and are used to treat allergic reactions, which can include allergic asthma symptoms. They do not precipitate asthma attacks.

 

Option B. Calcium channel blockers: Incorrect. While not commonly associated with precipitating asthma, calcium channel blockers are primarily used for treating hypertension and cardiac conditions and do not typically trigger asthma attacks.

 

Option D. Beta-adrenergic receptor agonists: Incorrect. Beta-adrenergic receptor agonists, such as albuterol, are actually used to relieve asthma symptoms by causing bronchodilation. They are a mainstay treatment for reversing acute bronchoconstriction in asthma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • NSAIDs are a class of drugs that can potentially precipitate acute asthma due to their effect on leukotriene pathways, which is crucial for managing patients with known asthma.
  • This awareness can guide healthcare providers in prescribing alternatives when treating such patients for pain or inflammation.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with sudden-onset, severe back pain that radiates to the chest. Her right arm BP is 70/40 mm Hg and left arm BP is 84/40 mm Hg. Which of the following diagnostic tests would be the best initial choice for immediate evaluation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) TEE (Transesophageal echocardiography)

 

  • Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) is the best initial diagnostic test for suspected aortic dissection.
  • It allows for rapid and detailed visualization of the aorta and heart structures, providing information on the location and extent of dissection.
  • TEE is especially useful for identifying dissections involving the ascending aorta (Type A) and can be performed quickly at the bedside.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chest X-ray PA view: Although a chest X-ray might reveal signs like mediastinal widening, it lacks the specificity required to diagnose an aortic dissection confidently.

 

Option B. Troponin: Troponin is a biomarker used primarily to detect myocardial infarction. While heart damage can accompany aortic dissection, it does not directly aid in diagnosing dissection.

 

Option C. MRI: Although MRI provides high-resolution images, it takes longer to perform and is less practical in emergency situations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) is the most appropriate initial diagnostic tool for suspected aortic dissection due to its ability to rapidly and accurately detect dissections involving the ascending aorta.

choices.text: Enhanced bone graft placement due to larger screw diameters
Increased ease of rod attachment due to the flexible angle of the screw heads
Reduced risk of spinal cord injury due to shorter screw length
Improved antibiotic delivery to the surgical site via the screw channels

questions.text: A 56-year-old male with chronic lower back pain undergoes spinal fusion surgery. During the procedure, the surgeon opts to use polyaxial pedicle screws. What is the primary advantage of using polyaxial pedicle screws in spinal fusion surgeries?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Increased ease of rod attachment due to the flexible angle of the screw heads

 

  • The primary advantage of polyaxial pedicle screws in spinal fusion surgeries lies in the design of the screw heads, which are capable of pivoting at various angles.
  • This flexibility allows the screws to be adjusted to align perfectly with the spinal rods, which is crucial during the complex process of spinal fusion.
  • This alignment is especially important in surgeries involving abnormal spinal curvatures or when precision is needed to optimize mechanical stability and reduce postoperative complications.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Enhanced bone graft placement due to larger screw diameters: This option is incorrect because the advantage of polyaxial screws is not associated with the size or diameter of the screws but rather with the functionality of their heads. The diameter of the screws does not directly influence the placement or effectiveness of bone grafts in spinal fusion.

 

Option C. Reduced risk of spinal cord injury due to shorter screw length: This choice is incorrect because the length of the screws generally pertains to the depth they can reach within the vertebral bone, which is chosen based on anatomical necessity rather than the type of screw head. Polyaxial screws do not inherently come in shorter lengths; their primary feature is the flexible head.

 

Option D. Improved antibiotic delivery to the surgical site via the screw channels: This is incorrect as polyaxial screws do not typically feature any design specifically intended for antibiotic delivery. While some screws are cannulated (hollow) to allow for such purposes, this is not a characteristic specific to polyaxial screws but rather to cannulated screws, which are a different category.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The flexible heads of polyaxial pedicle screws allow for an increased ease of rod attachment, making them particularly useful in spinal fusion surgeries to ensure proper alignment and stabilization.
  • This flexibility is a key advantage in managing complex spinal surgeries.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with multiple sclerosis reports difficulty walking and performing daily activities. On examination, her physical therapist notes significant weakening and shrinking of her leg muscles. What is the most likely cause of the observed changes in her muscle condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Atrophy

 

  • Muscle atrophy in this case is most likely due to disuse and secondary complications from multiple sclerosis, a neurological disorder that disrupts communication between the brain and various parts of the body.
  • The patient's difficulty in walking and performing daily activities suggests reduced physical activity, which leads to muscle disuse.
  • Over time, this inactivity results in a decrease in muscle mass and strength, a process known as atrophy.
  • Neurogenic atrophy occurs rapidly when muscles are not used, especially when nerve damage, as seen in multiple sclerosis, plays a role.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aplasia: This term refers to the absence of organ development. It is incorrect in this context because the patient's muscles were previously developed and functional; the issue arises from a decline in muscle condition, not from nonexistence.

 

Option B. Hypoplasia: Hypoplasia describes a condition where an organ or tissue is underdeveloped from birth. This choice is inappropriate as it implies a congenital condition, whereas the patient's muscle changes are acquired due to a progressive neurological disease and subsequent disuse.

 

Option D. Dystrophy: Dystrophy, particularly muscle dystrophy, involves a genetic component leading to progressive muscle degeneration. Although symptoms may appear similar, the patient's condition is primarily linked to multiple sclerosis and not a genetic muscle disorder, making this option incorrect for the scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Muscle atrophy can result from neurological diseases such as multiple sclerosis, which impair physical activity and lead to muscle disuse.
  • Maintaining muscle activity is crucial in managing and mitigating the effects of such conditions.

choices.text: To establish a bidirectional Glenn shunt
To create an atrial septal defect (ASD) for improved hemodynamics
To redirect blood flow from the right ventricle to both the pulmonary artery and aorta
To ligate the patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) and close the foramen ovale

questions.text: A 5-year-old child with congenital heart disease presents for surgical intervention. The surgical team plans to perform a Rastelli procedure. Which of the following best describes the primary aim of a Rastelli repair?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) To redirect blood flow from the right ventricle to both the pulmonary artery and aorta

 

  • The primary goal of a Rastelli procedure is to redirect blood flow from the right ventricle to both the pulmonary artery and aorta using a conduit.
  • This helps to correct complex congenital heart defects such as tetralogy of Fallot with pulmonary atresia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. To establish a bidirectional Glenn shunt: Incorrect. A bidirectional Glenn shunt is typically performed in staged palliation for certain congenital heart defects, but it is not the aim of a Rastelli repair.

 

Option B. To create an atrial septal defect (ASD) for improved hemodynamics: Incorrect. Creating an atrial septal defect (ASD) is not the goal of a Rastelli repair; instead, it involves redirecting blood flow at the ventricular level.

 

Option D. To ligate the patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) and close the foramen ovale: Incorrect. Ligation of the patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) and closure of the foramen ovale are procedures performed for other types of congenital heart defects and are not part of a Rastelli repair.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Rastelli procedure aims to redirect blood flow from the right ventricle to both the pulmonary artery and aorta, providing correction for complex congenital heart defects such as tetralogy of Fallot with pulmonary atresia.

choices.text: Add a P2Y12 receptor blocker

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman underwent coronary angiography after presenting with chest pain. The angiogram showed significant narrowing of the left circumflex artery, which was managed with stent insertion. She is currently taking aspirin 100 mg once daily, atenolol 50 mg twice daily, lovastatin, and lisinopril. Which additional medication would be most appropriate to improve post-stenting outcomes?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Add a P2Y12 receptor blocker

 

  • After stent placement, dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) is essential to prevent stent thrombosis.
  • This involves using both aspirin and a P2Y12 receptor blocker (such as clopidogrel, prasugrel, or ticagrelor).
  • DAPT reduces the risk of thrombotic events and improves patient outcomes after percutaneous coronary intervention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Add a long-acting nitrate: While nitrates can alleviate chest pain symptoms, they are not the primary step in managing patients post-stenting.

 

Option B. Increase the aspirin dose: Current guidelines suggest using aspirin at a low dose (75-100 mg/day) as part of DAPT, so increasing the dose beyond 100 mg isn't necessary.

 

Option C. Increase atenolol dose: Atenolol, a beta-blocker, helps manage angina and heart rate but isn't critical in preventing stent thrombosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In patients with coronary artery stenting, dual antiplatelet therapy using both aspirin and a P2Y12 receptor blocker is crucial for preventing stent thrombosis and reducing cardiovascular complications.

choices.text: Phase III Randomized control trial (RCT)
Phase II Randomized control trial (RCT)

questions.text: Which study design is most suitable for determining the highest dose of a new medication that can be administered safely?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Phase I trial

 

  • A Phase I trial is primarily concerned with assessing the safety of a new drug, including determining the maximum tolerable dose (MTD) in humans.
  • These trials are the first step in testing a new drug on humans and typically involve a small number of participants.
  • The goal is to identify how the drug is processed in the body and any side effects that occur as dosage increases to determine the safe dosage range for further studies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phase III Randomized Control Trial (RCT): This type of study is incorrect because Phase III trials are designed to confirm the effectiveness of a drug, compare it with standard or equivalent treatments, and collect additional information that will allow the drug to be used safely. They are not focused primarily on safety or maximum dosing but rather on efficacy and broader safety in a larger group.

 

Option B. Case-control study: This study design is also incorrect for determining the maximum tolerable dose as case-control studies are typically observational and used to assess and compare patients who have a specific condition (cases) with those who do not (controls), focusing more on understanding factors associated with disease or condition occurrence rather than drug safety or dosing.

 

Option C. Phase II Randomized Control Trial (RCT): This choice is incorrect because Phase II trials are primarily designed to assess the efficacy of a drug and further explore its safety within a larger group of people than in Phase I trials. While safety is a component of these trials, they do not specifically aim to establish the maximum tolerable dose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Phase I trials are specifically designed to determine the safety and maximum tolerable dose of a new drug in humans.
  • This is the fundamental purpose of this phase in the clinical trial process.

choices.text: Potassium - Mostly non-exchangeable, osmotically inactive
Calcium - Mostly exchangeable, osmotically active
Magnesium - Mostly exchangeable, osmotically inactive

questions.text: Which of the following solutes is correctly paired with its exchangeability and contribution to osmotic activity?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sodium - 65–70% exchangeable, osmotically active

 

  • Sodium ions in the body are about 65–70% exchangeable, meaning this fraction of the body’s sodium can be exchanged with sodium in the diet or excreted, which influences osmotic activity and therefore fluid balance.
  • This exchangeability and osmotic activity are crucial for maintaining proper fluid distribution and pressure within and outside cells.

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Potassium - Mostly non-exchangeable, osmotically inactive: Incorrect because nearly all of the body's potassium is in the exchangeable pool and is osmotically active, significantly influencing cell function.

 

Option C. Calcium - Mostly exchangeable, osmotically active: Incorrect as almost all of the body’s calcium is non-exchangeable and primarily stored in bones and teeth, contributing minimally to osmotic pressure in fluids.

 

Option D. Magnesium - Mostly exchangeable, osmotically inactive: Incorrect because similar to calcium, a significant portion of the body’s magnesium is non-exchangeable, primarily stored in bones and involved in various enzymatic reactions rather than contributing to osmotic activity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sodium is 65–70% exchangeable and osmotically active, essential for fluid balance, whereas potassium is mostly exchangeable and also osmotically active, influencing cellular functions.
  • Conversely, the majority of calcium and magnesium in the body is non-exchangeable and does not contribute significantly to osmotic activity.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with massive hematemesis. On upper GI endoscopy, “varix on varix” appearance was seen. What will be your next immediate step in the management of this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Variceal banding

 

  • Variceal banding is the initial treatment of choice for acute variceal bleeding.
  • Appearance of “varix on varix” implies varices which are enlarged and at risk of rupture.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. TIPSS (Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt): While TIPSS is an effective treatment for refractory variceal bleeding or as a bridge to definitive therapy, it is not typically the first-line intervention for acute variceal bleeding.

 

Option C. Trans abdominal gastroesophageal devascularization: This procedure, also known as the Sugiura procedure, is a surgical technique involving the ligation of esophageal and gastric vessels to reduce portal pressure. It is usually reserved for patients who fail endoscopic or medical therapy and is not the immediate next step in the management of acute variceal bleeding.

 

Option D. Balloon tamponade: Balloon tamponade (e.g., with Sengstaken-Blakemore tube) may be used as a temporizing measure to control bleeding while awaiting definitive therapy or in cases where other interventions are not immediately available. However, it is associated with significant risks and complications, including esophageal or gastric rupture, and should be used cautiously.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Variceal banding is the preferred initial treatment for acute variceal bleeding, as it effectively achieves hemostasis and reduces the risk of rebleeding.

choices.text: It is metabolised by liver
It has anti-secretory action in the gastrointestinal tract (GIT)
It is a drug used in constipation
It is a prodrug that is converted to a peripherally acting enkephalinase inhibitor

questions.text: A pharmacology professor is discussing the characteristics and uses of rececadotril with medical students as part of a pharmacology lecture. Which of the following statements about rececadotril is false?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is a drug used in constipation

 

  • Rececadotril is not used in the treatment of constipation; rather, it is used as an antidiarrheal agent.
  • Its mechanism involves being a prodrug that, once metabolized, converts into an active form which inhibits enkephalinase.
  • Enkephalinase inhibitors work to increase the levels of enkephalins, which are peptides that enhance water and electrolyte absorption in the intestines and reduce hypersecretion, thus effectively controlling diarrhea symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is metabolised by liver: True. Rececadotril is metabolized in the liver, where it is converted into its active form, thiorphan, which then exerts the pharmacological effects.

 

Option B.  It has anti-secretory action in GIT: True. Rececadotril exhibits its primary pharmacological action by reducing secretions in the gastrointestinal tract, making it effective in managing diarrhea.

 

Option D. It is a prodrug that is converted to a peripherally acting enkephalinase inhibitor: True. Rececadotril itself is inactive but is rapidly converted in vivo to thiorphan, which inhibits enkephalinase. This inhibition leads to reduced degradation of endogenous enkephalins, which helps decrease the secretion of water and electrolytes into the intestinal lumen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Rececadotril is used as an antidiarrheal, not for constipation.
  • Its primary mechanism involves enhancing the effects of endogenous enkephalins by inhibiting their degradation, which in turn helps control and reduce diarrhea by decreasing the secretion in the gastrointestinal tract.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presents with a headache and a burning sensation in his head. On physical examination, he has feeble lower limb pulses and elevated blood pressure (190/100 mm Hg). You also hear a continuous murmur in the infrascapular region. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Coarctation of the aorta

 

  • Coarctation of the aorta is a congenital condition characterized by narrowing of the aorta, often occurring near the ligamentum arteriosum.
  • This narrowing leads to increased blood pressure in the upper body and decreased blood flow to the lower body.
  • The discrepancy results in weak or absent lower limb pulses and hypertension affecting the upper extremities.
  • Elevated blood pressure and high-flow collateral vessels can lead to rib notching, evident on chest X-ray.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Patent Ductus Arteriosus: This condition involves a persistent connection between the aorta and the pulmonary artery, which typically presents with a machinery-like murmur best heard at the left upper sternal border, not with the symptoms described.

 

Option B. Aortic dissection: Aortic dissection involves a tear in the aortic wall, leading to severe pain and potential hemodynamic instability. Although it may lead to pulse discrepancies, it generally doesn't cause rib erosions.

 

Option D. ASD (Atrial septal defect): ASD is a congenital heart defect involving an abnormal opening between the atria. It primarily results in shunting and pulmonary hypertension, not causing blood pressure differences or rib erosions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Coarctation of the aorta often presents with upper body hypertension, weak lower limb pulses, and characteristic rib notching due to collateral circulation.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presents with blurred vision three months following cataract surgery. Fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA) is done which shows the following image. Identify the condition:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Irvine-Gass syndrome

 

  • The picture shows flower petal pattern on FFA due to pooling of dye in the cystoid spaces.
  • Irvine-Gass syndrome also known as cystoid macular edema (CME), commonly develops after cataract surgery and can show a flower petal pattern on FFA due to pooling of dye in the cystoid spaces.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. After-cataract: Refers to posterior capsular opacification following cataract surgery, not associated with the flower petal pattern seen in the FFA, which is indicative of cystoid changes in the retina.

 

Option C. Wet age-related macular degeneration: Characterized by choroidal neovascularization leading to bleeding and leakage, which can also appear on FFA but typically does not form a flower petal pattern.

 

Option D. Retinal vein occlusion: Leads to widespread hemorrhages and edema in the retina, visible on FFA as diffuse leakage rather than a structured pattern.

 

Educational Objective :
 

  • The flower petal pattern observed in FFA is a hallmark of Irvine-Gass syndrome, or cystoid macular edema, typically occurring after cataract surgery, distinguishing it from other macular abnormalities such as those found in diabetic retinopathy or wet AMD.

choices.text: Femoral neck fracture, Risser's cast
Femoral shaft fracture, spica cast
Femoral neck fracture, Minerva cast
Femoral shaft fracture, Minerva cast

questions.text: A 47-year-old female is evaluated 4 weeks following a leg fracture. The accompanying photo displays her leg in a cast, and she has not undergone any previous surgeries. Identify the likely type of fracture she experienced and specify the type of cast used?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Femoral shaft fracture, spica cast

 

  • The image shows a cast that encloses the hip, the entire femoral region down to the foot, with a supporting bar between the legs to stabilize and prevent rotation.
  • This type of cast is a spica cast, typically used for femoral shaft fractures to ensure proper alignment and immobilization during the healing process.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Femoral neck fracture, Risser's cast: This is incorrect as Risser's cast is primarily used for scoliosis treatment involving the spine, not for femoral neck fractures.

 

Option C. Femoral neck fracture, Minerva cast: Incorrect because Minerva casts are designed for cervical through upper thoracic immobilization, not for lower limb fractures.

 

Option D. Femoral shaft fracture, Minerva cast: Also incorrect, as the Minerva cast does not apply to femoral shaft injuries and is used for the cervical and upper thoracic spine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A spica cast is specifically designed to immobilize the lower torso and full length of the leg, making it ideal for managing femoral shaft fractures to promote proper healing and alignment.

questions.text: An ophthalmologist is evaluating treatment options for a patient with open-angle glaucoma. One of the drugs in glaucoma management focuses on inhibiting the rho kinase pathway. Which of the following drugs targets this specific pathway to reduce intraocular pressure?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Netarsudil

 

  • Netarsudil is specifically designed to address open-angle glaucoma and ocular hypertension by inhibiting the rho kinase pathway.
  • This action facilitates the increased outflow of aqueous humor through the trabecular meshwork and lowers episcleral venous pressure, effectively reducing intraocular pressure.
  • This mechanism is unique among glaucoma treatments, distinguishing Netarsudil from more traditional medications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bimatoprost: Incorrect. Bimatoprost is a prostaglandin analog similar to latanoprost, used to treat glaucoma by increasing the outflow of aqueous humor, but it does not inhibit the rho kinase pathway.

 

Option B. Dorzolamide: Incorrect. Dorzolamide is a topical carbonic anhydrase inhibitor that reduces aqueous humor production to lower intraocular pressure but does not work through rho kinase inhibition.

 

Option C. Brimonidine: Incorrect. Brimonidine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist that reduces aqueous humor production and increases uveoscleral outflow. While it effectively lowers intraocular pressure, it does not target the rho kinase pathway.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Netarsudil is notable for its unique mechanism involving rho kinase inhibition, a newer approach in the treatment of glaucoma that enhances aqueous humor outflow and reduces intraocular pressure, providing a distinct therapeutic option compared to traditional glaucoma medications.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with fatigue and massive splenomegaly. Laboratory tests show anemia, thrombocytosis, and leukocytosis with left shift. Bone marrow biopsy reveals hypercellularity, high myeloid to erythroid ratio with 6% myeloid blasts. Which test can confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) FISH

 

  • Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) and reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) are highly sensitive tests used to identify the BCR-ABL fusion gene associated with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML).
  • The BCR-ABL fusion results from a reciprocal translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22, known as the Philadelphia chromosome, and leads to the production of a constitutively active tyrosine kinase. Identifying this mutation confirms the diagnosis of CML.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PET: Positron emission tomography is used for detecting metabolic activity in malignancies but isn't specific for diagnosing CML.

 

Option B. LAP score: The leukocyte alkaline phosphatase score is lower in CML compared to leukemoid reactions, but it isn't sensitive enough to confirm the diagnosis.

 

Option C. Immunophenotyping: This technique helps identify cell markers in leukemia but doesn't specifically detect the BCR-ABL mutation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • FISH and RT-PCR are highly sensitive and specific for detecting the BCR-ABL fusion gene, making them the best tests for diagnosing chronic myeloid leukemia.

questions.text: A 32-year-old hiker presents with complaints of a painful, reddened area on his heel after a long day of trekking in new boots. On examination, there is a large, fluid-filled blister on the affected area. Which of the following types of inflammation is primarily involved in the formation of this blister?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Serous inflammation

 

  • Serous inflammation is primarily involved in situations where a clear, protein-rich fluid accumulates, such as in blisters formed due to burns or friction injuries.
  • In the scenario provided, the hiker developed a large blister as a result of the mechanical friction caused by new boots.
  • This blister is filled with serous fluid, indicative of serous inflammation, which is a bodily response to reduce friction and protect the underlying tissue while healing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Purulent inflammation:  This involves the production of pus and typically occurs with bacterial infections. The scenario describes a sterile blister caused by physical trauma rather than an infection, making purulent inflammation an incorrect answer.

 

Option B. Ulceration:  Ulceration refers to a breach in the skin or mucous membrane that fails to heal. In this case, the blister has not breached but has instead formed a protective fluid-filled layer over the skin, distinguishing it from ulceration.

 

Option C. Fibrinous inflammation: This type of inflammation involves the deposition of fibrin and is generally associated with more severe injuries or inflammations, particularly those that occur in body cavities or involve larger wounds. It is not typically associated with simple blister formation from friction.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Serous inflammation should be suspected in clinical scenarios involving clear, watery fluid collection, such as blisters from burns or friction injuries, where there is no sign of bacterial infection or more severe tissue damage.
  • This type of inflammation acts to protect and heal superficial injuries by creating a barrier between the damaged tissue and external environment.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant presents with failure to thrive, developmental delay, and hepatomegaly. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated serum levels of citrulline and ammonia. Which of the following inborn errors of metabolism is most likely responsible for these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency (OTC)

 

  • Ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency (OTC) is an X-linked disorder of the urea cycle, leading to the accumulation of ammonia and citrulline.
  • Patients typically present with hyperammonemia, hepatomegaly, and neurological symptoms.
  • The elevated ammonia levels contribute to the development of neurological symptoms such as developmental delay.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phenylketonuria (PKU):  Incorrect. Phenylketonuria (PKU) is characterized by elevated phenylalanine levels and presents with intellectual disability, seizures, and a musty odor of the urine. It does not typically present with hepatomegaly or elevated citrulline levels.

 

Option B. Maple syrup urine disease (MSUD):  Incorrect. Maple syrup urine disease (MSUD) leads to the accumulation of branched-chain amino acids (leucine, isoleucine, and valine) and presents with a characteristic sweet-smelling urine, ketoacidosis, and neurological symptoms. It does not cause elevated citrulline levels.

 

Option D. Gaucher disease: Incorrect. Gaucher disease is a lysosomal storage disorder characterized by the accumulation of glucocerebroside, leading to hepatosplenomegaly, cytopenias, and bone involvement. It does not cause elevated citrulline levels or hyperammonemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency (OTC) is an X-linked disorder of the urea cycle characterized by hyperammonemia, hepatomegaly, and neurological symptoms due to the accumulation of ammonia and citrulline.

questions.text: A neurologist is reviewing recent advancements in treatment for myasthenia gravis. Which of the following is not a newly approved drug for the treatment of myasthenia gravis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Vadadustat

 

  • Vadadustat is not approved for the treatment of myasthenia gravis.
  • It is actually a hypoxia-inducible factor prolyl hydroxylase (HIF-PH) inhibitor used primarily for the treatment of anemia in chronic kidney disease.
  • Vadadustat functions by mimicking the body's response to low oxygen levels, thereby stimulating the production of erythropoietin, which is unrelated to the pathophysiology of myasthenia gravis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rozanolixizumab: This is a monoclonal antibody targeting the neonatal Fc receptor, used in the treatment of myasthenia gravis. It works by reducing the pathogenic IgG autoantibodies, thereby improving symptoms.

 

Option B. Zilucoplan: This is a complement C5 inhibitor that has recently been approved for the treatment of myasthenia gravis by reducing the destruction of the neuromuscular junction which is mediated by the complement system in this autoimmune disorder.

 

Option C. Efgartigimod: This drug is an Fc receptor antagonist used in the treatment of myasthenia gravis. It lowers the levels of pathogenic IgG antibodies, including those that target the acetylcholine receptor, thus reducing the autoimmune attack that characterizes the disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Vadadustat is not used for treating myasthenia gravis but is instead indicated for anemia associated with chronic kidney disease.

choices.text: RANK (Receptor Activator of Nuclear Factor B)

questions.text: Bone pain is the most common symptom in multiple myeloma and patients tend to have lytic bone lesions due to secretion of a variety of osteoclast activating factors. However, bone scans in multiple myeloma are not useful in myeloma because osteoblasts are inhibited by:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) DKK1 (Dickkopf 1)

 

  • DKK1 (Dickkopf 1) is a protein that inhibits the Wnt signaling pathway, which is crucial for bone formation and remodeling.
  • In multiple myeloma, the increased expression of DKK1 leads to suppression of osteoblast activity, thereby inhibiting new bone formation.
  • This inhibition contributes to the predominance of osteolytic lesions seen on imaging and explains the ineffectiveness of traditional bone scans in detecting these lesions, as these scans rely on detecting new bone formation activity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. RANK RANK (Receptor Activator of Nuclear Factor B): Is involved in osteoclast activation and bone resorption, not directly in inhibiting osteoblasts.

 

Option C. MIP-1 Macrophage inflammatory protein-1 (MIP-1): Can enhance osteoclast activity and contribute to bone resorption but does not directly inhibit osteoblasts.

 

Option D. TNF: Tumor Necrosis Factor (TNF): Is a cytokine that can contribute to inflammation and bone resorption; however, its primary action is not the inhibition of osteoblasts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In multiple myeloma, bone scans are typically not useful due to the suppression of osteoblast activity by DKK1, leading to ineffective new bone formation. It provides insights into the pathophysiology of bone lesions in multiple myeloma.

questions.text:
A patient present to the emergency department with numbness and a burning sensation in the fingers and toes after prolonged cold exposure. Understanding the type of nerve fibers involved in transmitting temperature sensations is crucial for diagnosing his condition. Which combination of nerve fibers is most likely responsible for relaying temperature sensations to the patient's central nervous system?

 

  1. A
  2. Aδ
  3. B
  4. C
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2,4

 

  • Temperature sensations, particularly those involving pain and thermal sensations, such as cold, are primarily transmitted by Aδ and C nerve fibers.
  • Aδ fibers are responsible for transmitting the initial quick, sharp pain and cold sensation, while C fibers carry longer-lasting, duller pain and temperature signals that are more chronic and burning in nature.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. 1, 2: Incorrect because A fibers are involved in motor control of muscle spindles, not temperature sensation.

 

Option B. 2, 3: Incorrect as B fibers are mostly involved in transmitting autonomic nervous system information, not sensory information.

 

Option D. 1, 4: Incorrect because A fibers do not transmit temperature sensations, whereas C fibers are involved in transmitting temperature and pain sensations.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Aδ and C fibers are crucial for transmitting temperature and pain sensations, which is essential in assessing conditions related to thermal exposure and neuropathic pain.

choices.text: Sub hyoid bursitis
Dermoid cysts attached to hyoid bone

questions.text: Which of the following swellings do not move usually with deglutition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cystic hygroma

 

  • Cystic hygroma is a congenital malformation of the lymphatic system, commonly found in the neck, typically in the posterior triangle.
  • Unlike other swellings mentioned, cystic hygromas do not move with deglutition because they are usually located deep within the neck (posterior triangle of neck) and are not intimately related to the trachea and larynx.
  • Therefore, they do not demonstrate movement with swallowing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thyroglossal cyst: Thyroglossal cysts are midline swellings that arise from remnants of the thyroglossal duct. They are often mobile with swallowing or tongue protrusion due to their location along the path of the embryonic thyroglossal tract.

 

Option B. Sub-hyoid bursitis: Sub-hyoid bursitis, also known as suprasternal bursitis, may cause swelling in the suprasternal notch area. While it may be palpable in the region of the hyoid bone, it typically moves with deglutition.

 

Option D. Dermoid cysts attached to hyoid bone: Dermoid cysts are congenital cystic lesions that may be found in the neck and are often located near or attached to the hyoid bone. They may demonstrate some movement with swallowing if attached to hyoid bone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cystic hygromas, located deep within the neck, typically do not move with deglutition, unlike other swellings such as thyroglossal cysts, subhyoid bursitis, or dermoid cysts attached to the hyoid bone.

questions.text: In the management of a patient with both tuberculosis (TB) and AIDS, one antitubercular drug is particularly contraindicated due to its severe side effects in immunocompromised individuals. Which of the following antitubercular drugs should not be given to a patient suffering from both tuberculosis and AIDS?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Thiacetazone

 

  • Thiacetazone is an antitubercular medication that should not be used in patients who have both tuberculosis and AIDS.
  • The use of thiacetazone in HIV-infected patients is associated with a higher risk of severe adverse reactions, including potentially fatal skin reactions such as Stevens-Johnson syndrome and toxic epidermal necrolysis.
  • Due to these serious health risks, it is recommended to avoid this drug in patients with compromised immune systems, such as those with AIDS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pyrazinamide: This drug can be used in the treatment of both TB and AIDS, although it requires careful monitoring for liver toxicity and other side effects. It is not specifically contraindicated in AIDS patients.

 

Option B. Ethambutol: Ethambutol is also used in the treatment of TB and is not contraindicated in AIDS patients. It primarily needs monitoring for ocular toxicity but does not carry the same risk of severe skin reactions as thiacetazone.

 

Option D. INH (Isoniazid): Isoniazid is a cornerstone drug in the treatment of TB and is also safe to use in HIV-infected individuals, provided that there is appropriate management of potential hepatotoxicity and neurological side effects with the use of pyridoxine (Vitamin B6).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Thiacetazone is contraindicated in patients with both tuberculosis and AIDS due to the high risk of severe and potentially fatal skin reactions.
  • This makes it crucial to select antitubercular drugs carefully, considering the immune status of the patient to avoid life-threatening adverse reactions.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old patient with a long-standing history of type 2 diabetes presents for an ophthalmologic evaluation. The fundus examination reveals various retinal changes. Which of the following findings are associated with non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR)?

 

  1. Microaneurysms and retinal hemorrhages
  2. Hard exudates and cotton wool spots
  3. Venous beading and intra-retinal microvascular abnormalities
  4. Neovascularization and vitreous haemorrhage
  5. Venous beading and looping
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 3, 5

 

Explanation:

 

1. Microaneurysms and retinal hemorrhages: These are early signs of NPDR, resulting from damage to the retinal capillaries.

 

2. Hard exudates and cotton wool spots: Hard exudates are lipid deposits from leaking capillaries, and cotton wool spots are areas of nerve fiber layer infarction, both indicative of NPDR.

 

3. Venous beading and intra-retinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMA), & 5 venous beading and looping: Both are typical findings in NPDR, with venous beading indicating venous dilation and IRMA representing shunts within the retinal microvasculature.

 

4. Neovascularization and vitreous hemorrhage: These findings are indicative of proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR) and not typical of NPDR.

 

Educational Objective :


 

  • Identifying features specific to NPDR such as microaneurysms, hard exudates, and venous abnormalities is crucial in the ophthalmic evaluation of diabetic patients, distinguishing it from the more advanced proliferative stage which involves neovascularization.

choices.text: Hip held in adduction and internal rotation
Normal ESR and white blood cell counts
Widening of the joint space on ultrasound
History of a preceding upper respiratory infection

questions.text: Which of the following characteristics is least likely to be associated with transient synovitis of the hip?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hip held in adduction and internal rotation

 

  • Typically, this positioning (Hip held in adduction and internal rotation) is more characteristic of other conditions like septic arthritis, where pain exacerbates with such movements.
  • Transient synovitis of the hip, also known as toxic synovitis, is less likely to present with the hip held in adduction and internal rotation. 
  • In transient synovitis, the hip is usually held in a less painful position, typically flexion, abduction and external rotation (FABER). This position minimizes intracapsular pressure and is the most comfortable for them. 
  • Adduction and internal rotation would likely increase pain and pressure within the inflamed joint.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Normal ESR and white blood cell counts: This is likely to be associated with transient synovitis. While there might be a mild elevation in ESR or WBC in some cases, these markers are usually normal or only slightly elevated, which helps differentiate it from more severe infections like septic arthritis. Significantly elevated ESR and WBC counts raise suspicion for more serious conditions like septic arthritis.

 

Option C. Widening of the joint space on ultrasound: This is likely to be associated with transient synovitis. Ultrasound of the joint may indeed reveal widening of the joint space due to an effusion, which is a common finding in transient synovitis. 

 

Option D. History of a preceding upper respiratory infection: This is likely to be associated with transient synovitis. Transient synovitis often follows an upper respiratory infection, linking it to post-viral inflammation. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In transient synovitis of the hip, unlike other joint conditions such as septic arthritis, the hip is typically not held in adduction and internal rotation. 
  • Instead, it's often held in flexion, abduction and external rotation to minimize discomfort. This positioning is a crucial diagnostic clue in differentiating transient synovitis from more severe conditions.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male with no prior medical history presents to the clinic complaining of recurrent episodes of swelling and pain in his left calf. Imaging confirms repeated instances of deep vein thrombosis over the past two years. Coagulation profile including prothrombin time, partial thromboplastin time, and platelet count is normal. Which of the following abnormalities is most likely responsible for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Factor V mutation

 

  • Factor V mutation, specifically Factor V Leiden, is the most common inherited form of thrombophilia.
  • It increases the risk of developing deep vein thrombosis (DVT) by making the blood more prone to clotting.
  • This mutation affects the regulation of anticoagulant protein C, which normally inhibits coagulation factors V and VIII.
  • The mutation prevents the inactivation of Factor V, leading to prolonged clotting activity and an increased risk of thrombosis. In this patient, the presence of recurrent DVT episodes despite a normal coagulation profile strongly suggests a genetic factor like Factor V mutation.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Mutation in protein C:  While a deficiency in protein C can also lead to increased thrombotic events, it usually presents with other coagulation abnormalities, which are not mentioned in this scenario. The patient's normal coagulation profile suggests that protein C levels are likely normal.

 

Option B. Hyperhomocysteinemia: This condition involves elevated levels of homocysteine, which can contribute to vascular damage and thrombosis. However, it typically requires additional risk factors such as vitamin B deficiency or renal disease, none of which are indicated in this patient's history.

 

Option D. Antithrombin III deficiency: This deficiency would also typically alter standard coagulation tests and lead to abnormal clotting, which was not observed in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In young patients presenting with unexplained recurrent DVTs and normal routine coagulation tests, consider genetic causes like Factor V Leiden mutation, particularly if there is no evidence of other acquired risk factors for thrombosis.
  • This highlights the importance of considering a genetic workup in the differential diagnosis of recurrent thrombotic events.

choices.text: Sodium: 45 mmol/L, Potassium: 40 mmol/L, Chloride: 70 mmol/L
Sodium: 130 mmol/L, Potassium: 20 mmol/L, Chloride: 90 mmol/L
Sodium: 75 mmol/L, Potassium: 30 mmol/L, Chloride: 65 mmol/L
Sodium: 110 mmol/L, Potassium: 30 mmol/L, Chloride: 80 mmol/L

questions.text: A 2-year-old child with severe acute malnutrition is admitted to the hospital with dehydration. The medical team initiates (RESOMAL) rehydration solution for the malnourished. Which of the following electrolyte concentrations is most appropriate for this scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sodium: 45 mmol/L, Potassium: 40 mmol/L, Chloride: 70 mmol/L

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When managing dehydration in malnourished children, it's essential to use (RESOMAL) rehydration solution for the malnourished which is made by 2 litre water, one packet ORS, 45ml syrup potklor which has potassium and 50gm dextrose.

questions.text: A hematologist is considering treatment options for a patient diagnosed with Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH). Recent advancements have introduced new therapeutic drugs for PNH. Which of the following drugs is a recently approved treatment option for managing symptoms and complications associated with PNH?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Danicopan

 

  • Danicopan is a factor D inhibitor in complement pathway that has recently been approved for the treatment of Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH).
  • It is a complement inhibitor which reversibly binds to factor D to prevent alternative pathway-mediated hemolysis and deposition of complement C3 proteins on red blood cells.
  • By controlling the complement cascade, it helps to prevent red blood cell breakdown, improve anemia, and reduce the need for blood transfusions in PNH patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nivolumab: Incorrect. Nivolumab is a PD-1 immune checkpoint inhibitor primarily used in the treatment of various cancers, such as melanoma and non-small cell lung cancer. It is not indicated for PNH.

 

Option C. Ocrelizumab: Incorrect. Ocrelizumab is a monoclonal antibody against CD20 used mainly in the treatment of multiple sclerosis. It has no role in the treatment of PNH.

 

Option D. Ustekinumab: Incorrect. Ustekinumab is an interleukin-12 and interleukin-23 inhibitor used to treat autoimmune diseases such as psoriasis and Crohn's disease. It is not used for PNH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Danicopan represents a significant advancement in the treatment of Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria by targeting and inhibiting the C3 component of the complement system by binding to factor D, thus effectively reducing hemolysis and its associated symptoms.

questions.text: In a cardiology training program, medical fellows are tasked with interpreting the ejection fraction (EF) from the diagram of a left ventricular pressure-volume loop. The ejection fraction is a vital indicator of the heart's pumping efficiency and overall cardiac health. Using the graph provided, calculate the ejection fraction and select the appropriate option below:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 66%

 

  • The ejection fraction (EF) is calculated from the left ventricular pressure-volume loop by identifying the end-diastolic volume (EDV) and the end-systolic volume (ESV).
  • EDV is the maximum volume of the ventricle just before it begins to contract (point D on the loop), and ESV is the volume remaining in the ventricle after it has contracted (point B on the loop).
  • The values from the loop are approximately 150 ml for EDV and 50 ml for ESV. The ejection fraction formula is:

 

 

  • This calculation indicates that the ejection fraction is approximately 66%, corresponding to option D.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The ejection fraction (EF) measures the percentage of blood the left ventricle ejects with each contraction and is calculated using the formula: EF = ((EDV - ESV) / EDV) × 100%.
  • It's a crucial indicator of cardiac efficiency and health, with normal values typically ranging from 55% to 70%.

choices.text: Disseminated TB involving bone marrow

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presents with gum bleeding, easy bruisability, and fatigue. He reports a fever lasting for a month. On physical examination, he appears pale, with a petechial rash over his body. A peripheral smear shows macrocytes, and his corrected reticulocyte count is 0.5%. Bone marrow aspiration reveals fatty streaks, no immature cells, and no inflammatory cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Idiopathic acquired aplastic anemia

 

  • Aplastic anemia is a bone marrow failure condition characterized by pancytopenia and an absence of immature cells in the bone marrow.
  • In idiopathic acquired aplastic anemia, the bone marrow biopsy typically shows a fatty replacement of marrow elements.
  • The patient's presentation with macrocytic anemia, low reticulocyte count, and pancytopenia aligns with aplastic anemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Disseminated TB involving bone marrow: Although tuberculosis can infiltrate bone marrow, it usually presents with granulomas or caseation and may not cause a fatty marrow appearance.

 

Option C. Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH): PNH leads to intravascular hemolysis and dark urine but typically presents with normocytic anemia.

 

Option D. Myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS): MDS often involves dysplastic changes and immature cells in the marrow, which aren't consistent with a fatty marrow replacement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Idiopathic acquired aplastic anemia presents with pancytopenia, a low reticulocyte count, and a fatty replacement of bone marrow cells.

choices.text: ERCP with sphincterotomy
Excision with Roux-en-Y Hepaticojejunostomy

questions.text: Identify the treatment of the pathology in the image below, seen in a young girl child with jaundice:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) ERCP with sphincterotomy

 

  • The pathology shown in the image appears to be choledochal cyst type 3.
  • In a young girl child with jaundice and choledochal cyst type 3, the treatment of choice is ERCP (Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography) with sphincterotomy.
  • This procedure allows for drainage of the bile and relieves the obstruction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lap cholecystectomy: Laparoscopic cholecystectomy is the treatment of choice for symptomatic cholelithiasis (gallstones).

 

Option C. Excision with Roux-en-Y Hepaticojejunostomy: This procedure is performed in type 1,2 and 4B choledochal cysts.

 

Option D. Whipple’s procedure: Whipple's procedure, also known as pancreaticoduodenectomy, is a complex surgery performed for tumors involving the head of the pancreas or periampullary region.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a young girl child with jaundice and choledochal cyst type 3, ERCP with sphincterotomy is the preferred treatment.

questions.text: Match the image with the refractive errors:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-d, 2-b, 3-a, 4-c

 

Image and its inference:

 

1-d (Normal vision): Light focuses directly on the retina, resulting in clear vision.

 

2-b (Hypermetropia): Light focuses behind the retina due to a shorter eyeball or less curved lens, commonly corrected with converging lenses.

 

3-a (Myopia): Light focuses in front of the retina because the eyeball is too long or the lens is too curved, typically corrected with diverging lenses.

 

4-c (Astigmatism): Light is focused unevenly due to an irregularly shaped cornea or lens, causing distortion and blurring at multiple distances.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Understanding how light focuses in various refractive errors is crucial for diagnosing and correcting vision issues like myopia, hyperopia, and astigmatism, each requiring specific types of corrective lenses to ensure proper vision.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man arrives at the emergency department following a severe crush injury to his arm. The medical team is concerned about the risk of developing gangrene and the potential onset of sepsis. They are deliberating whether to proceed with amputation or attempt limb salvage. To best determine the appropriate course of action between amputation and limb salvage in the context of a severe crush injury to the upper limb, which of the following would be most useful?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) MESS (Mangled Extremity Severity Score)

 

  • The correct answer is Mangled Extremity Severity Score (MESS).
  • MESS is a specific scoring system designed to help clinicians determine the likelihood of limb salvage success in cases of severe limb injuries.
  • It considers factors such as limb ischemia, patient age, shock, and injury mechanism.
  • A higher MESS score suggests a higher likelihood that amputation may be necessary, whereas a lower score supports attempts at limb salvage.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gustilo-Anderson classification: The Gustilo-Anderson classification is incorrect because it is primarily used to classify open fractures based on the extent of the wound and contamination but does not directly guide decisions between amputation and limb salvage.

 

 

Option B. ASIA guidelines: ASIA guidelines, pertaining to spinal injury assessments, are incorrect as they are irrelevant to decisions regarding limb salvage or amputation in cases of upper limb injuries.

 

 

 

Option C. GCS score: The GCS (Glasgow Coma Scale) score is incorrect as it assesses the level of consciousness in trauma patients and is not used to determine the management of limb injuries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Mangled Extremity Severity Score (MESS) is crucial in assessing the viability of limb salvage versus the need for amputation in severe limb injuries.
  • It incorporates multiple factors that help predict the potential success of salvaging a severely injured limb.

choices.text: Level of glucose-6-phosphatase in liver cells
Level of α1-antitrypsin in the liver
Number of LDL receptors on hepatocytes
Level of sphingomyelinase in splenic macrophages

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl is evaluated for persistent abdominal enlargement and a recent onset of frequent falls and tremors. Her parents note she has become less responsive and more irritable over the past year. Examination reveals a significantly enlarged liver and spleen. A biopsy of the spleen shows numerous foamy macrophages. Which of the following tests is most likely to confirm the suspected diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Level of sphingomyelinase in splenic macrophages

 

  • The clinical presentation of persistent abdominal enlargement, neurological symptoms such as frequent falls and tremors, and irritability, coupled with hepatosplenomegaly and the histological finding of foamy macrophages in a spleen biopsy, strongly suggests a lysosomal storage disease, specifically Niemann-Pick disease.
  • This condition is characterized by a deficiency of the enzyme sphingomyelinase, which is crucial for the breakdown of sphingomyelin, a lipid found in cell membranes.
  • The deficiency leads to the accumulation of sphingomyelin, causing the characteristic foamy appearance of macrophages.
  • Testing the level of sphingomyelinase in splenic macrophages will confirm the diagnosis by showing a reduced enzyme activity.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Level of glucose-6-phosphatase in liver cells: This enzyme is related to glycogen storage diseases, particularly von Gierke disease, which presents mainly with metabolic abnormalities such as hypoglycemia and not with neurological symptoms or foamy macrophages.

 

Option B. Level of α1-antitrypsin in the liver:  Deficiency in α1-antitrypsin typically leads to pulmonary complications and liver disease, not the neurological symptoms or the storage of sphingomyelin seen in Niemann-Pick disease.

 

Option C. Number of LDL receptors on hepatocytes:  This factor is significant in conditions like familial hypercholesterolemia, where there's an increased cholesterol level due to insufficient LDL receptor function, not related to the symptoms of lysosomal storage diseases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In cases presenting with hepatosplenomegaly, neurological decline, and biopsy findings of foamy macrophages, consider lysosomal storage diseases such as Niemann-Pick disease.
  • Testing for sphingomyelinase activity in splenic macrophages is diagnostic for this condition.

questions.text: A 14-month-old infant presents with sudden-onset high fever followed by a maculopapular rash spreading from the trunk to the extremities. On examination, the child appears well-appearing with resolved fever. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Roseola infantum 

 

  • Roseola infantum, also known as exanthem subitum or sixth disease, typically presents with sudden-onset high fever lasting 3-5 days, followed by the development of a maculopapular rash spreading from the trunk to the extremities.
  • By the time the rash appears, the fever has usually resolved.
  • The child appears well-appearing during the rash phase. This presentation is characteristic of roseola infantum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Varicella: Incorrect. Varicella presents with a prodrome of fever and malaise followed by the appearance of vesicular lesions in different stages of development, starting on the trunk and spreading to the extremities.

 

Option B. Measles: Incorrect. Measles (Rubeola) presents with a prodrome of fever, cough, coryza, and conjunctivitis followed by the appearance of a maculopapular rash starting on the face and spreading downward.

 

Option D. Hand, foot, and mouth disease: Incorrect. Hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) presents with fever, sore throat, and characteristic oral lesions (ulcers) along with vesicular rash on the hands and feet, not typically associated with sudden-onset high fever and subsequent rash.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Roseola infantum (Exanthem subitum) is characterized by sudden-onset high fever lasting 3-5 days, followed by the appearance of a maculopapular rash spreading from the trunk to the extremities.
  • The child appears well-appearing during the rash phase, distinguishing it from other childhood exanthems.

choices.text: Decrease the absorption of antihypertensive drugs
Decrease the synthesis of vascular prostacyclin
Increase the clearance of antihypertensive drugs

questions.text: A patient who is currently on antihypertensive medication reports a recent increase in blood pressure readings. The patient has also been using non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) for chronic joint pain. Which of the following explains why NSAIDs might blunt the effectiveness of antihypertensive treatments?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Decrease the synthesis of vascular prostacyclin

 

  • NSAIDs blunt the effectiveness of antihypertensive drugs primarily by decreasing the synthesis of vascular prostacyclin.
  • Prostacyclin is a potent vasodilator and inhibitor of platelet aggregation produced by the endothelium.
  • It plays a significant role in vascular homeostasis by promoting vasodilation and maintaining lower blood pressure levels.
  • NSAIDs inhibit the cyclooxygenase (COX) enzymes, which are crucial for the synthesis of prostacyclins.
  • This inhibition leads to reduced vasodilation, counteracting the effects of antihypertensive drugs, especially those that depend on vasodilation to lower blood pressure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decrease the absorption of antihypertensive drugs: This is incorrect because NSAIDs do not significantly impact the gastrointestinal absorption of antihypertensive medications. Their interaction is more related to pharmacodynamic effects rather than pharmacokinetic ones involving absorption processes.

 

Option C. Increase the clearance of antihypertensive drugs: Also incorrect. NSAIDs do not generally increase the metabolic clearance of antihypertensive drugs via liver enzyme induction or other mechanisms. Their effect is more directly related to their impact on prostaglandin synthesis.

 

Option D. Cause sodium excretion: This option is incorrect. NSAIDs typically cause sodium retention, not excretion, by affecting renal blood flow and impairing the kidney's ability to excrete sodium. This action would actually contribute to increased blood pressure, further complicating the management of hypertension.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • NSAIDs can interfere with the effectiveness of antihypertensive drugs by decreasing the synthesis of vascular prostacyclin, a key vasodilator, through their inhibition of COX enzymes.
  • This interaction is a significant consideration in managing patients on antihypertensive therapy who also require NSAID treatment.

choices.text: The first secretory phase is reduced
Beta cell function is reduced by as much as 90% at the onset of type 2 diabetes mellitus
Response to arginine is preserved

questions.text: Which of the following statements about initial insulin resistance or impaired insulin secretion is not true?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Beta cell function is reduced by as much as 90% at the onset of type 2 Diabetes Mellitus

 

  • Beta cell function is impaired at the onset of type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM), but it is not reduced to 90% of its capacity initially.
  • Instead, studies suggest a more modest reduction in beta cell function.
  • The primary feature of early T2DM is insulin resistance, and beta cells compensate by increasing insulin secretion until they become progressively unable to maintain glucose homeostasis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glucose-stimulated insulin secretion is reduced: This statement is correct because glucose-stimulated insulin secretion is impaired early in the disease.

 

Option B. The first secretory phase is reduced: The first phase of insulin secretion is often diminished or absent in individuals with T2DM.

 

Option D. Response to arginine is preserved: Arginine-stimulated insulin secretion remains relatively intact in early T2DM, reflecting partial beta cell function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Beta cell function does not decline by 90% at the onset of type 2 diabetes mellitus.
  • Instead, the decline is gradual and progresses over time.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease presents with a decreased arterial oxygen level. His arterial blood gases show a PO2 of 70 mm Hg, while the alveolar gas measurements indicate a PO2 of 73 mm Hg. What is the most likely explanation for the difference in partial pressure of oxygen between the arterial and alveolar measurements?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Physiological shunt

 

  • Physiological shunting occurs when some of the blood bypasses the alveoli without participating in gas exchange.
  • This phenomenon is normal to a small degree in everyone due to blood supply to the bronchial circulation and areas of the lung where ventilation and perfusion are not perfectly matched.
  • In the case presented, the slight difference between the alveolar PO2 (73 mm Hg) and arterial PO2 (70 mm Hg) suggests a mild physiological shunt, possibly exacerbated by underlying chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, which is known to worsen V/Q mismatch.

 

Other options:


 

Option B. Physiological dead space: Refers to the portion of the lungs that is ventilated but not perfused adequately with blood. In this scenario, physiological dead space would not cause a decrease in arterial PO2 relative to alveolar PO2; instead, it could potentially increase it due to mixing of oxygen-rich dead space air with alveolar air.

 

Option C. Pathological shunt: Pathological shunt, such as from intracardiac shunts or severe intrapulmonary shunts, would typically result in a much larger decrease in arterial PO2 and is associated with more severe clinical manifestations than described in the patient scenario.

 

Option D. Anatomical dead space: It is the volume of air in the respiratory passages that does not participate in gas exchange, such as the air in the trachea and bronchi. It does not influence the difference in PO2 between alveolar and arterial blood, as it contains no blood flow and only impacts the efficiency of ventilation.

 

Educational Objective:


The concept of physiological shunt, a normal mechanism where some blood bypasses the alveoli, which can be exaggerated in diseases such as COPD, leading to a small discrepancy between alveolar and arterial PO2 levels.

choices.text: ESWL (Extracorporeal Shock Wave Lithotripsy)
Wait and watch
Plain CT KUB

questions.text: A patient comes with pain in the left flank. On imaging, the following is obtained. What is the next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
An. D) Plain CT KUB

 

  • The image provided shows a radiopaque shadow in the left ureter, suggestive of a ureteric calculus. The next step in the management of this patient is to perform a Plain CT KUB) to further evaluate the size, location, and presence of stones in other sites like renal stones.
  • CT KUB provides detailed imaging of the urinary tract, helping to assess the degree of obstruction, stone size, and presence of any associated complications such as hydronephrosis or infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ESWL (Extracorporeal Shock Wave Lithotripsy): While ESWL is a non-invasive treatment option for ureteric stones, it is typically reserved for smaller stones (<2 cm) located in the upper and mid ureter. Before proceeding with ESWL, a Plain CT KUB is usually performed to assess stone size, location, and composition.

 

Option B. Uretero-renoscopic removal (URS): Uretero-renoscopic removal, also known as ureteroscopy, is a minimally invasive procedure used to directly visualize and remove stones from the ureter. However, it is usually performed after obtaining detailed imaging with Plain CT KUB to guide the surgical approach and ensure optimal stone removal.

 

Option C. Wait and watch: With the presence of symptomatic ureteric calculus, a conservative approach of "wait and watch" without further evaluation or intervention is not recommended. Prompt assessment and management are essential to relieve symptoms and prevent complications associated with ureteric stones.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a patient presenting with flank pain suggestive of ureteric calculus, the next step in management is to perform a Plain CT KUB to assess stone characteristics and guide further treatment decisions.

choices.text: It is especially useful for reducing phacoemulsification power needed in cases of mature dense cataract
It is particularly helpful for centring the rhexis in cases of patients undergoing Toric/Multifocal Intraocular Lens Implants
It is particularly helpful for small pupil cases
The order of performing the three main steps is as follows: first, anterior capsulotomy; second, lens fragmentation and or liquefaction; and third, the corneal incisions

questions.text: Regarding the use of femtosecond laser for cataract surgery all of the following are true except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is particularly helpful for small pupil cases

 

  • The statement about femtosecond lasers being particularly helpful for small pupil cases is incorrect.
  • While femtosecond lasers provide many benefits in cataract surgery, such as precise capsulotomies and reduced phacoemulsification energy, they are not specifically advantageous for small pupil cases.
  • In fact, small pupils can pose challenges for femtosecond laser procedures because adequate dilation is necessary to ensure the laser accurately performs the capsulotomy and lens fragmentation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is especially useful for reducing phacoemulsification power needed in cases of mature dense cataract: Femtosecond lasers are useful in mature dense cataracts as they can reduce the energy needed for phacoemulsification by pre-fragmenting the lens, thereby decreasing the risk of complications from ultrasonic energy.

 

Option B. It is particularly helpful for centring the rhexis in cases of patients undergoing Toric/Multifocal Intraocular Lens Implants: The technology allows for precise centring and sizing of the capsulotomy, which is crucial for the optimal positioning and performance of Toric and Multifocal IOLs.

 

Option D. The order of performing the three main steps is as follows: first, anterior capsulotomy; second, lens fragmentation and or liquefaction; and third, the corneal incisions: The listed order of steps for femtosecond laser-assisted cataract surgery (anterior capsulotomy, lens fragmentation, then corneal incisions) is standard as it ensures the procedure is efficient and minimizes intraocular manipulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Femtosecond laser technology enhances many aspects of cataract surgery but is not specifically designed to handle small pupil cases more effectively than traditional methods.

choices.text: Gastrocnemius and Soleus muscle tear

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient is brought to the emergency department by paramedics after sustaining a comminuted fracture of the tibia in a motor vehicle accident. The patient complains of severe calf pain, which worsens with dorsiflexion of the foot, and reports numbness on the sole of the foot. Despite these symptoms, the distal pulses are intact. Given the patient's symptoms and injury history, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Compartment syndrome

 

  • Compartment syndrome is the correct diagnosis given the symptoms of severe pain, particularly on dorsiflexion of the foot, and sensory deficits such as numbness in the sole of the foot.
  • This condition occurs when pressure within the muscle compartments builds up to dangerous levels, potentially leading to muscle and nerve damage due to decreased blood flow.
  • The presence of a comminuted fracture increases the likelihood of bleeding and swelling within the compartments, exacerbating the pressure increase.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tarsal tunnel syndrome: Tarsal tunnel syndrome is incorrect because it primarily involves entrapment of the posterior tibial nerve in the tarsal tunnel near the ankle, which does not typically relate to the symptoms described following a tibia fracture.

 

Option B. Rupture of Achilles tendon: Rupture of Achilles tendon is incorrect as it would mainly present with inability to stand on tiptoes and a palpable gap in the tendon, rather than calf pain induced by dorsiflexion and numbness on the sole.

 

Option D. Gastrocnemius and Soleus muscle tear: Gastrocnemius and Soleus muscle tear is incorrect because such an injury would not typically present with symptoms exacerbated by dorsiflexion of the foot and would more likely show localized bruising and swelling without the described pattern of numbness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Compartment syndrome should be suspected in patients with fractures who exhibit severe pain, especially on movement, and sensory disturbances, as it requires urgent intervention to prevent permanent damage.
  • Distal pulses may still be present even in the setting of compartment syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of primary hyperparathyroidism in multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN 1)?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypercalcemia is usually severe

 

  • In primary hyperparathyroidism associated with MEN 1, hypercalcemia is typically mild to moderate in severity, not severe.
  • Primary hyperparathyroidism in MEN 1 is characterized by an earlier age at onset, affecting both genders equally, and parathyroid cancer is uncommon.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Earlier age at onset: Patients with MEN 1 often present with primary hyperparathyroidism at an earlier age than those with sporadic cases.

 

Option B. Equal male-to-female ratio: The condition affects both males and females equally in MEN 1.

 

Option D. Parathyroid cancer is rare: Malignant transformation of parathyroid adenomas to cancer is extremely rare.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In MEN 1, primary hyperparathyroidism usually presents at an earlier age, affects both genders equally, and rarely involve parathyroid cancer.

choices.text: Loss of cell cycle arrest

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with hemoptysis and a worsening cough. Examination reveals wheezes over the right lung posteriorly. Chest x-ray shows a 6-cm perihilar mass. Biopsy identifies non-small cell bronchogenic carcinoma, and molecular analysis reveals a p53 gene mutation. What mechanism most likely led to this neoplastic transformation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Loss of cell cycle arrest

 

  • The p53 gene is known as the "guardian of the genome" due to its role in maintaining genomic stability.
  • It encodes a protein responsible for initiating cell cycle arrest, DNA repair, or apoptosis in response to cellular stress or DNA damage.
  • A mutation in the p53 gene impairs its function, leading to a loss of cell cycle arrest.
  • As a result, the cells continue to divide despite genomic abnormalities, allowing further accumulation of mutations and promoting neoplastic transformation.
  • This is a common pathway in the development of many cancers, including non-small cell bronchogenic carcinoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Microsatellite instability: This refers to a genetic condition involving defects in DNA mismatch repair genes, which is characteristic of hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer (Lynch syndrome) but not directly linked to p53 mutations.

 

Option B. Inability to hydrolyze GTP: GTP hydrolysis is a process involving GTPases like RAS, which can also contribute to cancer if mutated. However, p53 mutations do not affect GTP hydrolysis mechanisms.

 

Option D. Lack of necrosis: Necrosis is a form of cell death due to injury. While necrosis may occur in tumors, it is not a primary mechanism driven by p53 mutations. Instead, these mutations primarily prevent cell cycle arrest and apoptosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A p53 gene mutation leads to loss of cell cycle arrest, resulting in unchecked cellular division and neoplastic transformation.

questions.text: A neonate is diagnosed with hypoplastic left heart syndrome (HLHS) shortly after birth. The surgical team plans to perform a palliative procedure to address the underdeveloped left side of the heart. Which of the following procedures is most appropriate for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Norwood procedure

 

  • The Norwood procedure is the initial palliative surgical intervention performed in neonates with hypoplastic left heart syndrome (HLHS). It involves constructing a new aorta, connecting it to the right ventricle, and rerouting blood flow from the right ventricle to the systemic circulation.
  • This procedure allows the right ventricle to function as the main pumping chamber for the body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blalock-Taussig shunt: Incorrect. The Blalock-Taussig shunt is a surgical procedure used to provide pulmonary blood flow in conditions where there is inadequate pulmonary blood flow, such as in Tetralogy of Fallot or pulmonary atresia. It is not the primary surgical approach for HLHS.

 

Option C. Fontan procedure: Incorrect. The Fontan procedure is the final stage in the surgical management of certain congenital heart defects, such as single ventricle physiology, where the systemic venous return is directed passively to the pulmonary arteries without passing through the ventricle.

 

 Option D. Glenn procedure: Incorrect. The Glenn procedure, also known as bidirectional Glenn shunt, is a staged palliative surgery typically performed in the treatment of congenital heart defects such as hypoplastic left heart syndrome (HLHS). However, it is not the initial procedure and is usually performed as an interim step between the Norwood procedure and the Fontan procedure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Norwood procedure is the initial palliative surgical intervention performed in neonates with hypoplastic left heart syndrome (HLHS), aiming to reroute blood flow to the systemic circulation and allow the right ventricle to function as the main pumping chamber for the body.

questions.text: A patient is being treated for cardiovascular risk factors, including high platelet aggregation. The physician discusses the role of nitric oxide in reducing platelet aggregation with medical interns during ward rounds. Which of the following substances is increased by nitric oxide to produce its anti-aggregatory action?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) cGMP

 

  • Nitric oxide (NO) exerts its anti-aggregatory effects on platelets primarily through the increase of cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP).
  • NO, a soluble gas produced by endothelial cells, diffuses into platelets and stimulates soluble guanylate cyclase (sGC).
  • This enzyme catalyzes the conversion of guanosine triphosphate (GTP) into cGMP.
  • Elevated levels of cGMP lead to a series of intracellular signaling events that result in decreased intracellular calcium levels, ultimately inhibiting platelet aggregation and promoting vasodilation.
  • This pathway is critical in maintaining vascular homeostasis and preventing thrombotic events.

 

Other Options:
