Option A. ADP: Incorrect. ADP (adenosine diphosphate) actually promotes platelet aggregation rather than inhibiting it. ADP binds to its receptors on platelets, triggering a cascade that increases platelet activation and aggregation.

 

Option B. Phosphoinositol: Incorrect. Phosphoinositol pathways are involved in various cellular functions, including signal transduction and lipid signaling, but they are not the primary mechanism by which nitric oxide mediates its anti-aggregatory effects.

 

Option D. cAMP: Incorrect. Although cAMP is another cyclic nucleotide involved in inhibiting platelet aggregation, nitric oxide specifically increases levels of cGMP, not cAMP, to exert its anti-aggregatory effects. cAMP’s role in reducing platelet aggregation is generally mediated by other substances like prostacyclin.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Nitric oxide reduces platelet aggregation by increasing the levels of cGMP in the platelets, thereby inhibiting their ability to clump together.
  • This mechanism is key in the regulation of blood flow and prevention of thrombosis.

questions.text: During a routine physiology lecture, a professor discusses the regulation of respiratory rhythm in humans. She explains the initiation of the RAMP signal. Which of the following regions in the brain is primarily responsible for initiating the RAMP signal?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pre-Bötzinger complex

 

  • Pre-Bötzinger complex is critical for generating the respiratory rhythm and is particularly associated with the initiation of the RAMP signal during respiration.
  • The RAMP signal is a gradual increase in inspiratory drive that results in smooth, controlled inspiration.
  • The Pre-Bötzinger complex's role in this process is fundamental to normal breathing patterns, and it functions as the primary pacemaker for breathing.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Pneumotaxic centre: The Pneumotaxic centre is involved in regulating the rate and pattern of breathing but primarily acts to limit inspiration and promote a smoother transition between inhalation and exhalation. It does not initiate the RAMP signal.

 

Option C. Dorsal respiratory group (DRG): The Dorsal respiratory group (DRG) primarily processes sensory information and contributes to the regulation of breathing by influencing the depth and rate. However, it does not initiate the RAMP signal; instead, it responds to chemical and mechanical changes in the body.

 

Option D. Ventral respiratory group (VRG): The Ventral respiratory group (VRG) contains both inspiratory and expiratory neurons and is involved in generating the basic rhythm of breathing and active expiration, but it does not directly initiate the RAMP signal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pre-Bötzinger complex plays a central role in initiating the RAMP signal, crucial for generating a smooth and sustained inspiratory phase in respiratory rhythm.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man presents to the neurology clinic with complaints of vivid visual hallucinations. He describes seeing people and animals that appear real but vanish suddenly. The hallucinations often occur at night when he is lying in bed. He recently had a stroke involving the thalamic and midbrain regions. Which arterial occlusion is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Posterior cerebral artery

 

  • The posterior cerebral artery (PCA) supplies the occipital lobes, thalamus, and midbrain.
  • Occlusion or infarction of the PCA can lead to a range of neurological deficits depending on the affected region.
  • Peduncular hallucinosis involves vivid, dream-like visual hallucinations and often results from a stroke or lesion in the thalamic or midbrain regions, typically supplied by the PCA.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterior cerebral artery: This artery supplies the frontal lobes and is associated with personality changes, cognitive deficits, and contralateral leg weakness when occluded.

 

Option B. Middle cerebral artery: Occlusion of the middle cerebral artery (MCA) results in contralateral hemiparesis, sensory loss, and aphasia, especially if the dominant hemisphere is involved.

 

Option D. Internal carotid artery: Internal carotid artery occlusion typically causes symptoms due to a lack of blood supply to the MCA and anterior cerebral artery (ACA) territories.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Peduncular hallucinosis, characterized by vivid visual hallucinations, is commonly associated with lesions in the thalamus and midbrain.
  • These regions are supplied by the posterior cerebral artery, making its occlusion a key cause of this phenomenon.

choices.text: Parathyroid multiglandular disease
Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor

questions.text: Which of these is the least likely finding expected in MEN 1 syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pheochromocytoma

 

  • Pheochromocytoma is more commonly associated with other syndromes such as Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 2 (MEN 2) or von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) syndrome, rather than MEN 1 syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pituitary prolactinoma: Pituitary adenomas, including prolactinomas, are common findings in MEN 1 syndrome, occurring in approximately 30-40% of affected individuals.

 

Option C. Parathyroid multiglandular disease: Parathyroid tumors leading to multiglandular disease and hyperparathyroidism are a hallmark feature of MEN 1 syndrome, occurring in nearly all affected individuals.

 

Option D. Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor: Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors, including gastrinomas, insulinomas, and glucagonomas, are frequently observed in MEN 1 syndrome, occurring in approximately 40-70% of affected individuals.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • While various endocrine tumors can occur in MEN 1 syndrome, including pituitary adenomas, parathyroid tumors, and pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors, the least likely finding among the options listed is pheochromocytoma.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents to the eye clinic complaining of progressive blurring of vision and frequent changes in his eyeglass prescription. He reports a history of eye rubbing and has noticed an increased sensitivity to light. A topographic image of the eye shows the following image. Based on the clinical presentation and imaging findings, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Keratoconus

 

  • Keratoconus: Characterized by a progressive thinning and conical protrusion of the cornea, leading to visual distortion, increased light sensitivity, and frequent changes in eyeglass prescription. This diagnosis aligns with the patient's symptoms and the topographic findings of a conical cornea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pterygium: Involves a benign growth of the conjunctiva that encroaches onto the cornea but does not cause the conical deformation typical of keratoconus.

 

Option C. Corneal ulcer: Typically presents with pain, redness, and often discharge, associated with an infectious or traumatic lesion of the cornea, which is not indicated by a conical shape on topography.

 

Option D. Astigmatism: Although it involves irregularities in the curvature of the cornea leading to blurred vision, it does not lead to the conical protrusion seen in keratoconus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Keratoconus is diagnosed based on clinical signs of corneal protrusion and visual symptoms, confirmed with imaging techniques like corneal topography that reveal the characteristic cone-shaped deformation of the cornea.
  • Early identification is crucial for managing the progression and planning for potential therapeutic interventions such as corneal cross-linking or specialized contact lenses.

choices.text: Conversion of smooth muscle cells to foam cells
Alterations of hepatic lipoprotein receptors
Endothelial injury and its sequelae

questions.text: A research study examining the process of atherogenesis explores the significant risk factors for developing atherosclerosis, which include smoking, hypertension, and hypercholesterolemia. The study evaluates these factors in experimental models of atherosclerosis. Which of the following is the primary biological consequence directly resulting from these risk factors?
questions.solution:
Ans.  D) Endothelial injury and its sequelae

 

  • Endothelial injury is a critical early event in the development of atherosclerosis, triggered by risk factors like smoking, hypertension, and hypercholesterolemia.
  • Once endothelial cells are damaged, they become permeable to lipoproteins, facilitating the infiltration of low-density lipoprotein (LDL) particles.
  • This leads to the accumulation of lipids, inflammatory cell recruitment, and subsequent endothelial dysfunction, thus promoting atheroma formation.
  • The resulting sequelae include further lipid accumulation, inflammation, and plaque progression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Conversion of smooth muscle cells to foam cells: While this is a crucial event in plaque formation, it is a subsequent step following endothelial injury. The damage to the endothelium allows LDL particles to accumulate, oxidize, and attract macrophages, which, in turn, ingest the oxidized LDL and transform into foam cells.

 

Option B. Inhibition of LDL oxidation: The oxidation of LDL is essential in foam cell formation and subsequent plaque development. However, this process is secondary to endothelial injury, which is considered the initiating step.

 

Option C. Alterations of hepatic lipoprotein receptors: Although changes in hepatic lipoprotein receptors can influence systemic cholesterol levels, they are not the primary direct consequence of the risk factors mentioned. These changes primarily affect cholesterol metabolism rather than causing endothelial damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Endothelial injury, directly resulting from risk factors like smoking, hypertension, and hypercholesterolemia, is the most important initiating event in atherogenesis, leading to subsequent lipid accumulation, foam cell formation, and plaque progression.

choices.text: Hyperkalemic periodic paralysis

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with a history of muscle stiffness and difficulty relaxing her grip after holding objects. She reports that her symptoms worsen with repetitive activities, particularly in cold environments. Based on these findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Paramyotonia congenita

 

  • Paramyotonia congenita is a rare inherited disorder characterized by myotonia that worsens with repetitive activity and cold exposure.
  • Unlike myotonia congenita, paramyotonia congenita involves a paradoxical worsening of muscle stiffness with repetitive movements.
  •  It is caused by mutations in the SCN4A gene, which codes for a voltage-gated sodium channel essential for muscle function.
  • Cold temperatures exacerbate symptoms, leading to increased stiffness and difficulty relaxing muscles.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Myotonia congenita: Myotonia congenita also involves muscle stiffness but improves with repetitive activity (the "warm-up" phenomenon) and is not influenced by cold.

 

Option B. Hyperkalemic periodic paralysis: This condition primarily features episodes of muscle weakness or paralysis rather than sustained myotonia.

 

Option C. Potassium-sensitive myotonia: While potassium-sensitive myotonia also features myotonia, it does not present with worsening stiffness due to cold temperatures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Paramyotonia congenita is characterized by muscle stiffness that paradoxically worsens with repetitive activity and cold exposure, helping distinguish it from other myotonic disorders.
